comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: Information from the CWGC registers: BERRIDGE, W E Rank: Second Lieutenant Date of Death: 20/08/1916 Age: 22 Regiment/Service: Somerset Light Infantry 6th Bn. Grave Reference: III. C. 18. Cemetery: HEILLY STATION CEMETERY, MERICOURT-L'ABBE [Somme, France] Additional Information: Born at Redhill, Surrey. Son of William Alfred and Beatrice Berridge, of 7, Radnor Park West, Folkestone. www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/270283/BERRIDGE,%20W%20E W. E. B. (William Eric Berridge) also published a volume entitled Verses in 1916; privately printed, Chichester Press, London (printers) See also: anepistolaryproject.wordpress.com/tag/william-eric-berridge/

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: London Gazette, 2 December 1914, p.10274: "The undermentioned Cadets and ex-Cadets of the Officers Training Corps to be temporary Second Lieutenants. Dated 2nd December, 1914:-- [...] William Eric Berridge." www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/28993/supplements/10274/

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: Berridge's poem "The Rat" occasionally seems to turn up in war poetry anthologies, e.g. the Wordsworth Book of First World War Poetry (Ware: Wordsworth Editions, 1995); it (p. 7) notes that Berridge died of wounds at Delville Wood

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: A "snippet" from Anne Powell, A Deep cry: a literary pilgrimage to the battlefields and cemeteries of First World War British soldier-poets killed in Northern France and Flanders (Aberporth: Palladour Press, 1993), ISBN 0952167808, found on Google Books, provides the following information: SECOND LIEUTENANT WILLIAM ERIC BERRIDGE 'C Company, 6th Battalion Somerset Light Infantry. Born: 3rd August 1894. Redhill, Surrey. Educated: Eton College. New College, Oxford. Died of Wounds: 20th August 1916. Aged 22 years.

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: From the (privately published) List of Etonians who fought in the Great War (1921), via the Internet Archive: p. 21 (printed in red, because he died): 1913 Berridge, W. E., 2nd Lt. Somerset L. I. France (d. w. 20.8.16) K.S. [1913 would appear to be the year that Berridge left Eton; “d” means died, “w” wounded; “K.S.” refers to his membership of College, meaning that he was a King's Scholar.] A separate list attached to the same book confirms that Berridge died (or at least received his fatal wounds) at Delville Wood. archive.org/details/listofetonianswh00eton

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: I found a couple of references to his father, William Alfred Berridge, who was apparently a surgeon: London Gazette, 1 January 1892, p. 24: “NOTICE is hereby given, that the Partnership heretofore subsisting between us the undersigned, Constantine Holman, Frederick Blackwood Hallowes, John Walters, and William Alfred Berridge, carrying on business as Surgeons, at Reigate and Redhill, Surrey, under the style or firm of Holman, Hallowes, Walters, and Berridge, will be dissolved, by effluxion of time, as and from the 31st day of December, 1891.—Dated this 29th day of December, 1891. C. HOLMAN. JOHN WALTERS. FRED. B. HALLOWES. W. A. BERRIDGE.” www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/26239/pages/24/ There is also a reference in Access to Archives to records relating to the insertion of stained glass window in memory of a William Alfred Berridge at St. Matthew's Church, Redhill, 1924; in the archives of the Diocese of Southwark held by the London Metropolitan Archives (DS/FO/1924/54/1-5): www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/a2a/records.aspx?cat=074-ds_2...

comment.author: 13082373@N02
comment._content: Fascinating that he perished in the Great War nearly a hundred years ago, and achieved temporary rank of 2nd Lt. at age 20. His poetry published, little bits of his life turn up every now and then, and here his photograph and all the searches reconstruct parts of his life and death. And though he probably thought, "No one will remember me a hundred years from now" and yet here we are remembering him, roughly a hundred years hence.
